Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial on Fiberoptic Intubation in Simulated Cervical Spine Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: The trial used computer-generated randomisation with allocation concealed in sealed envelopes. The sample size was calculated to detect significant differences with a power of 92%.

Participants.evidence: Sixty adult patients, aged 18-65, requiring nasotracheal intubation for oral surgery were randomly assigned... Conducted at the Fourth Affiliated Hospital of Zhejiang University Medical College

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to continuous positive-pressure oxygen (CPO), normal-pressure (NS), or intermittent negative-pressure suction (INS) groups.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the efficiency and safety of fiberoptic intubation under different air pressures in patients with simulated cervical spine injury after anesthesia induction.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was intubation time, measured from bronchoscope insertion to tracheal intubation completion, with a maximum of 180 seconds.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: The trial used computer-generated randomisation with allocation concealed in sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to the outcome assessor.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty adult patients... were randomly assigned

Result_Outcome.evidence: The median intubation time was significantly shorter in the CPO group (59 seconds) compared to the NS (167 seconds) and INS (132.5 seconds) groups (P=0.04).

Harms.evidence: One patient in the INS group experienced minor mucosal bleeding.
